title: 110_hr3407
content: The Act is titled the "Positive Behavior for Effective Schools Act." It includes findings and purposes for the Act. The Congress finds that disciplinary issues are a major challenge in schools, zero tolerance approaches are ineffective, successful schools have high academic and behavior standards, evidence-based practices for behavior improvement are not widely adopted, and early intervention services can prevent many problems. Intervening services like positive behavior supports lead to academic achievement, fewer disciplinary problems, and increased opportunities for all students. Schoolwide positive behavior supports improve behavior by using active supervision, positive feedback, and social skills instruction. Positive behavior support, when combined with effective interventions for students with significant needs, benefits all students. The Act aims to expand the use of positive behavior supports in schools to create a conducive learning environment, reduce discipline issues, and enhance academic outcomes for all students, including those with challenging behaviors. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 defines positive behavior support as a range of strategies to achieve social and learning outcomes while preventing problem behavior. This is part of the Act's goal to implement schoolwide positive behavior support to improve academic outcomes and reduce discipline issues. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 allows flexibility to use Title I funds for schoolwide positive behavior support, including early intervening services for all students needing academic and behavioral support. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 allows flexibility to use Title I funds for schoolwide positive behavior support and additional academic and behavioral support in a general education environment. Funds allocated must supplement, not supplant, funds under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act. Technical assistance includes support for implementing schoolwide positive behavior supports and evidence-based approaches. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 allows flexibility to use Title I funds for schoolwide positive behavior support and additional academic and behavioral support in a general education environment. Technical assistance includes support for implementing schoolwide positive behavior supports and evidence-based approaches. Amendments are made to various sections of the Act to include funding for technical assistance centers on schoolwide positive behavior supports. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 allows flexibility to use Title I funds for schoolwide positive behavior support and improving the learning environment in schools. Amendments include funding for technical assistance centers on schoolwide positive behavior supports. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 allows flexibility to use Title I funds for schoolwide positive behavior support to improve academic outcomes for students. SEC. 5. AMENDMENTS RELATED TO THE SAFE AND DRUG-FREE SCHOOLS AND COMMUNITIES PROGRAM. The purpose of Section 4002 of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is to support programs that improve school climate, prevent discipline problems, violence, and substance abuse, involve parents and communities, and coordinate efforts to create a safe and drug-free learning environment. This includes providing Federal assistance to States for grants to local educational agencies. States provide grants to local educational agencies and consortia to establish, operate, and improve programs focusing on improving school climate, including positive behavior supports. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include early intervening services that improve school climate for learning, such as positive behavior supports. Additionally, there is a provision for teacher professional development to enhance school climate. SEC. 7 amends the Elementary and Secondary Education Act to include an understanding of social/emotional learning and approaches to improve school climate. SEC. 8 establishes the Office of Specialized Instructional Support Services. The Office of Specialized Instructional Support Services, under the Department of Education, aims to improve academic achievement by providing specialized instructional support services in schools. It is headed by a Director appointed by the Secretary of Education. The Office of Specialized Instructional Support Services, part of the Department of Education, focuses on improving academic achievement through specialized instructional support services for students. This includes identifying effective practices, providing training for personnel, offering technical assistance to educational agencies, and coordinating programs between federal agencies. SEC. 9. REFERENCES TO PUPIL SERVICES AND PERSONNEL. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to replace "pupil services" with "specialized instructional support services" and "pupil services personnel" with "specialized instructional support personnel." Additionally, Section 9101 is amended to include definitions for "specialized instructional support personnel" and "specialized instructional support services." The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to replace "pupil services" with "specialized instructional support services" and "pupil services personnel" with "specialized instructional support personnel." Specialized instructional support personnel include school counselors, social workers, psychologists, and other professionals providing necessary services to meet student needs.
